Ground Rules for Training
Ground Rules for Training

• Please be on time. • Put cell phones on vibrate. • Forget about the “office.” • Stay focused on “Learning the System.”
• Please be on time.
• Put cell phones on vibrate.
• Forget about the “office.”
• Stay focused on “Learning the System.”

– No reading of emails.

• Ask questions. • Limit sidebar conversations. • Respect others.

Chapter 3 Manually Adding Assets
Chapter 3
Manually Adding Assets

All Assets
All Assets

• Assets must be entered into ENCOMPASS
• Assets must be entered into ENCOMPASS

– Valued at $500 or Greater – Agencies can (optional) enter assets valued at less than $500
– Valued at $500 or Greater
– Agencies can (optional) enter assets valued at less than $500

• Assets must include the following information:
• Assets must include the following information:

– Tag Number – Location – Custodian (active employee listed in HR) – Chartfields (Fund, Department, Program, Bud Ref.)
– Tag Number
– Location
– Custodian (active employee listed in HR)
– Chartfields (Fund, Department, Program, Bud Ref.)

• Agencies may require additional fields: Project, Product, Locality
• Agencies may require additional fields: Project, Product, Locality

All Assets
All Assets

• The State requires all Assets be acquired via

– Used in limited situations

Workflow

• All Financial Transactions require Financial

– Basic Adds

• Assets valued at $20,000 and greater will

require Auditor of State approval: – Exception: Retirements
require Auditor of State approval:
– Exception: Retirements

email with the FAM’s denial comments.

• Only to be used in specific circumstances:

– Assets discovered during inventory

• Transaction Date = In Service Date • Assets are sent to the AM Approver by clicking
• Transaction Date = In Service Date

the “Submit Workflow” button
the “Submit Workflow” button

• Assets are capitalized automatically by the final

approval
approval

– A 7 digit alpha-numeric field defined by the Agency

– The person responsible for (or primary user) of the asset

Copy an Asset
Copy an Asset

• Copy an Asset can be used when:
• Copy an Asset can be used when:

– There are multiple number of Assets to be added. – The asset shares similar Physical and Financial information
– There are multiple number of Assets to be added.
– The asset shares similar Physical and Financial information

to the original Asset. • Copy an Asset Options:
to the original Asset.
• Copy an Asset Options:

– Select the information to be copied. – Change the Physical and Financial information as needed.
– Select the information to be copied.
– Change the Physical and Financial information as needed.

• New Asset IDs are automatically assigned
• Other adjustments can be made via Basic Add

or Adjustment pages
or Adjustment pages

Chapter 4 Adjusting, Recategorizing and Transferring Assets
Chapter 4
Adjusting, Recategorizing and Transferring
Assets

Adjust Assets
Adjust Assets

• Adjustments are necessary to:
• Adjustments are necessary to:

– Update Asset Records – Correct Errors – Add newly received information
– Update Asset Records
– Correct Errors
– Add newly received information

• Common types of adjustments include:
• Common types of adjustments include:

– Add a new cost row – Adjust the total cost – Recategorize an asset – Transfer an asset to another Department, Business Unit, etc.
– Add a new cost row
– Adjust the total cost
– Recategorize an asset
– Transfer an asset to another Department, Business Unit, etc.

Note – Financial changes cannot be made via Basic Add pages
Note – Financial changes cannot be made via Basic Add pages

once the asset has been capitalized.
once the asset has been capitalized.

Transfer/Adjustment Steps
Transfer/Adjustment Steps

• The State of Indiana uses a three-step process
• The State of Indiana uses a three-step process

to transfer/adjust assets:
to transfer/adjust assets:

– Step 1: Enter the Asset Transfer/Adjustment – Step 2: Approval by Financial Asset Manager
– Step 1: Enter the Asset Transfer/Adjustment
– Step 2: Approval by Financial Asset Manager

» AOS, for assets valued at $20,000 or greater
» AOS, for assets valued at $20,000 or greater

– Step 3: Run the Finalization
– Step 3: Run the Finalization

Transfers/Adjustments
Transfers/Adjustments

• Asset are not updated until:
• Asset are not updated until:

– All necessary approvals have been received – Finalization has been processed
– All necessary approvals have been received
– Finalization has been processed

» Additional changes can not be made until the previous
» Additional changes can not be made until the previous

changes have been approved, denied or finalized.
changes have been approved, denied or finalized.

• Changes are updated on the Cost History pages
• Changes are updated on the Cost History pages

– Not via Basic Add pages
– Not via Basic Add pages

• Asset Changes must be sent to the AM Approver
• Asset Changes must be sent to the AM Approver

– Click on the “Submit Workflow” button
– Click on the “Submit Workflow” button

Note - Asset Status can be reviewed by using the Review Approvals page.
Note - Asset Status can be reviewed by using the Review
Approvals page.

Transfer Policy
Transfer Policy

• State of Indiana Transfer Policy:
• State of Indiana Transfer Policy:

– All transfers, sales, retirements and other
– All transfers, sales, retirements and other

disposals of capital assets must be processed and approved by the State Surplus Property division of IDOA by submitting Form 13812, Notification of Surplus State-Owned Property.
disposals of capital assets must be
processed and approved by the State
Surplus Property division of IDOA by
submitting Form 13812, Notification of
Surplus State-Owned Property.

Transfers
Transfers

IntraUnit Transfer – Transfer an Asset within a Business Unit, typically used to
IntraUnit Transfer
– Transfer an Asset within a Business Unit, typically used to

update Chartfield values.
update Chartfield values.

» Fund, Department, Program, Project, etc.
» Fund, Department, Program, Project, etc.

InterUnit Transfer – Transfer an Asset to another Business Unit.
InterUnit Transfer
– Transfer an Asset to another Business Unit.

» The chartfield values of receiving Business Unit are
» The chartfield values of receiving Business Unit are

required to enter transaction.
required to enter transaction.

Viewing Cost History
Viewing Cost History

• Cost History displays information for
• Cost History displays information for

capitalized and non-capitalized assets – List pages: shows history of asset’s transactions – Detail pages: shows detailed information regarding
capitalized and non-capitalized assets
– List pages: shows history of asset’s transactions
– Detail pages: shows detailed information regarding

financial transactions
financial transactions

• Cost History displays all financial transactions
• Cost History displays all financial transactions

that occurred to after the asset was capitalized
that occurred to after the asset was capitalized

Note - Basic Add only shows cost information from the time
Note - Basic Add only shows cost information from the time

the asset was capitalized.
the asset was capitalized.

Chapter 5 Retiring and Reinstating Assets
Chapter 5
Retiring and Reinstating Assets

Retirement Policy
Retirement Policy

• Assets are considered retired if disposed of in
• Assets are considered retired if disposed of in

any of the following ways: – Sent to State Surplus (property division) – Traded In – Scrapped – Sold at Public Auction – Sold to Local Unit of Government – Stolen (reported to Capital Police prior to processing)
any of the following ways:
– Sent to State Surplus (property division)
– Traded In
– Scrapped
– Sold at Public Auction
– Sold to Local Unit of Government
– Stolen (reported to Capital Police prior to processing)

Types of Retirement
Types of Retirement

• Three 3 basic types of retirements:
• Three 3 basic types of retirements:

– Full, when all quantities & costs of an asset are retired – Partial, when only a portion of the quantities & costs of an
– Full, when all quantities & costs of an asset are retired
– Partial, when only a portion of the quantities & costs of an

asset are retired. (NOT used by SOI)
asset are retired. (NOT used by SOI)

– Prior Period, when an asset is retired in a prior accounting
– Prior Period, when an asset is retired in a prior accounting

period but not recorded until next period
period but not recorded until next period

• Reinstatements can occur at any time, and are
• Reinstatements can occur at any time, and are

used: – To correct errors – To place an asset back into service
used:
– To correct errors
– To place an asset back into service

Retirement Options
Retirement Options

• The State of Indiana uses the following retirement
• The State of Indiana uses the following retirement

options: – Casualty Loss – Disposal Due to Theft - (police report filed) – Duplicate Asset – Missing Asset – Retirement by Sale – Scrapped Asset - (no value to surplus) – State Surplus – Traded In for Another Asset
options:
– Casualty Loss
– Disposal Due to Theft - (police report filed)
– Duplicate Asset
– Missing Asset
– Retirement by Sale
– Scrapped Asset - (no value to surplus)
– State Surplus
– Traded In for Another Asset

• Accounting entries are automatically generated based
• Accounting entries are automatically generated based

on the retirement option selected
on the retirement option selected

Retirement Warning
Retirement Warning

• Retirements – cautionary notes:
• Retirements – cautionary notes:

– Assets can be retired, even if unprocessed Financial Transactions
– Assets can be retired, even if unprocessed Financial Transactions

exist
exist

– Once retired, Financial Transactions can not be Finalized
– Once retired, Financial Transactions can not be Finalized

• Verify all Financial Transactions have a status of
• Verify all Financial Transactions have a status of

“Completed” prior to retiring any asset
“Completed” prior to retiring any asset

Navigation: Asset Management > Asset Transactions > Financial
Navigation: Asset Management > Asset Transactions > Financial

Transactions > Review Transfer/Adj. Approvals
Transactions > Review Transfer/Adj. Approvals

Reinstating Assets
Reinstating Assets

• Reinstatement can be used on retired Assets:
• Reinstatement can be used on retired Assets:

– To correct errors – To place an asset back in service • When reinstatement occurs:
– To correct errors
– To place an asset back in service
• When reinstatement occurs:

– All journal entries created for retired asset are reversed – If depreciation has not processed for the retired asset,
– All journal entries created for retired asset are reversed
– If depreciation has not processed for the retired asset,

reinstatement will remove the RET transaction from the Cost table
reinstatement will remove the RET transaction from the
Cost table

Retirements/Reinstatements
Retirements/Reinstatements

• When the Retirement/Reinstatement is saved:
• When the Retirement/Reinstatement is saved:

– Asset status is immediately changed • Retirement – status changes to “Disposed” • Reinstatement – status changes to “In Service” – Asset is automatically placed into workflow If the retirement/reinstatement is denied: – Asset status does not automatically return to previous status – AM Entry must take necessary action to change the status
– Asset status is immediately changed
• Retirement – status changes to “Disposed”
• Reinstatement – status changes to “In Service”
– Asset is automatically placed into workflow
If the retirement/reinstatement is denied:
– Asset status does not automatically return to previous status
– AM Entry must take necessary action to change the status

• Denied Retirement = Reinstate the asset • Denied Reinstatement = Retire the asset
• Denied Retirement = Reinstate the asset
• Denied Reinstatement = Retire the asset

Disposal Worksheet
Disposal Worksheet

• Disposal Worksheet is used to:
• Disposal Worksheet is used to:

– Dispose of several assets at one time – Dispose of assets that have common data, such as: Profile ID,
– Dispose of several assets at one time
– Dispose of assets that have common data, such as: Profile ID, – D i s p o s e

Category, Department, etc.

• Three step process:
• Three step process:

– Select Assets for Disposal – Approve Disposal Worksheet – Process the Transaction Loader
– Select Assets for Disposal
– Approve Disposal Worksheet
– Process the Transaction Loader

• Locate the Interface ID

• Asset Information Tab contains:

Interfaces
Interfaces

• Asset Status created by the Interface:
• Asset Status created by the Interface:

– PO Receipt adds the Asset Status of “Received (Not in
– PO Receipt adds the Asset Status of “Received (Not in

Service)”
Service)”

– AP Voucher automatically capitalizes the asset for the voucher amount and changes the Asset Status to “In Service”
– AP Voucher automatically capitalizes the asset for the
voucher amount and changes the Asset Status to “In
Service”

Interfaces process automatically – AM Entry Users can process the interfaces manually
Interfaces process automatically
– AM Entry Users can process the interfaces manually

• Four steps to interface Receipts/Vouchers into
• Four steps to interface Receipts/Vouchers into

Asset Management: – Pre-Interface tables, Interface Loader, Consolidate /
Asset Management:
– Pre-Interface tables, Interface Loader, Consolidate /

Unitize, and Transaction Loader
Unitize, and Transaction Loader

Integration Process Flow
Integration Process Flow

Integration
Integration

• Four integration steps involved:
• Four integration steps involved:

– Step 1 involves pushing the Receipt or Voucher
– Step 1 involves pushing the Receipt or Voucher

information from Procurement into AM. It will process automatically.
information from Procurement into AM. It will process
automatically.

– Step 2 is the Interface Loader. It pulls information from the
– Step 2 is the Interface Loader. It pulls information from the

Pre-Interface table and populates the Physical and Financial tables. It will process automatically.
Pre-Interface table and populates the Physical and
Financial tables. It will process automatically.

– Step 3 is Consolidation/Unitization. This is manually controlled and must be processed prior to Step 4.
– Step 3 is Consolidation/Unitization. This is manually
controlled and must be processed prior to Step 4.

– Step 4 is the Transaction Loader. It creates the asset. It
– Step 4 is the Transaction Loader. It creates the asset. It

will process automatically.
will process automatically.

Consolidate / Unitize
Consolidate / Unitize

• Consolidation is used to combine several
• Consolidation is used to combine several

components into a single asset.
components into a single asset.

• Unitization is used to convert asset lines from PO Receipts or Vouchers with multiple asset quantities into separate assets having a quantity of one.
• Unitization is used to convert asset lines from
PO Receipts or Vouchers with multiple asset
quantities into separate assets having a
quantity of one.

• Consolidation / Unitization must be completed prior to processing the Transaction Loader.
• Consolidation / Unitization must be completed
prior to processing the Transaction Loader.

Chapter 6 Maintaining Parent-Child Assets
Chapter 6
Maintaining Parent-Child Assets

Parent-Child Asset Relationships
Parent-Child Asset
Relationships

• Parent-Child Assets:
• Parent-Child Assets:

– Grouped together for processing and reporting – Three methods of grouping assets:
– Grouped together for processing and reporting
– Three methods of grouping assets:

• Single asset with multiple acquisition detail lines for each
• Single asset with multiple acquisition detail lines for each

component
component

• One component designated as the parent with the
• One component designated as the parent with the

remaining components as child assets
remaining components as child assets

• Parent only asset with each component as a child asset
• Parent only asset with each component as a child asset

– Each component can have its own cost, depreciation,
– Each component can have its own cost, depreciation,

and physical information
and physical information

Navigation: Asset Management > Asset Transactions > Parent-Child
Navigation: Asset Management > Asset Transactions > Parent-Child

Relationship > Review Parent - Child
Relationship > Review Parent - Child

Adding Parent-Child Assets
Adding Parent-Child Assets

• Parent-Child Assets are added via Basic Add • Parent Asset must be established prior to
• Parent-Child Assets are added via Basic Add
• Parent Asset must be established prior to

assigning any Child Assets
assigning any Child Assets

• Child Assets can have a cost and depreciation
• Child Assets can have a cost and depreciation

independent of the Parent
independent of the Parent

• Once established, special security is required
• Once established, special security is required

to change a Parent-Child designation
to change a Parent-Child designation

Retiring Parent-Child Assets
Retiring Parent-Child Assets

• Parent-Child Assets can be retired by: – Retiring the parent and all child assets – Retiring the parent and some child assets – Retiring just the child assets – Retiring just some of the child assets
• Parent-Child Assets can be retired by:
– Retiring the parent and all child assets
– Retiring the parent and some child assets
– Retiring just the child assets
– Retiring just some of the child assets

Chapter 7 Correcting ChartField Errors
Chapter 7
Correcting ChartField Errors

ChartField Edit
ChartField Edit

• A custom Chartfield Edit process was created to run after Accounting Entries are created to: – Validate ChartField values – Validate Chartfield combinations – Flag any Chartfield errors
• A custom Chartfield Edit process was created
to run after Accounting Entries are created to:
– Validate ChartField values
– Validate Chartfield combinations
– Flag any Chartfield errors

• Line errors must be correct in order to post accounting information to General Ledger
• Line errors must be correct in order to post
accounting information to General Ledger

Note – Agencies are responsibility for reviewing and correcting any identified ChartField errors at the end of each month.
Note – Agencies are responsibility for reviewing and correcting
any identified ChartField errors at the end of each month.
